segment.source: This article shows how to use the APIs in the Windows.Media.Audio namespace to create audio graphs for audio routing, mixing, and processing scenarios.
segment.target: This article shows how to use the APIs in the Windows.Media.Audio namespace to create audio graphs for audio routing, mixing, and processing scenarios.

segment.source: Audio Graphs
segment.target: Audio Graphs

segment.source: Audio Graphs
segment.target: Audio Graphs

segment.source: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.
segment.target: \[ Updated for UWP apps on Windows 10.

segment.source: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]
segment.target: For Windows 8.x articles, see the archive \]

segment.source: This article shows how to use the APIs in the Windows.Media.Audio namespace to create audio graphs for audio routing, mixing, and processing scenarios.
segment.target: This article shows how to use the APIs in the Windows.Media.Audio namespace to create audio graphs for audio routing, mixing, and processing scenarios.

segment.source: An audio graph is a set of interconnected audio nodes through which audio data flows.
segment.target: An audio graph is a set of interconnected audio nodes through which audio data flows.

segment.source: Audio input nodes supply audio data to the graph from audio input devices, audio files, or from custom code.
segment.target: Audio input nodes supply audio data to the graph from audio input devices, audio files, or from custom code.

segment.source: Audio output nodes are the destination for audio processed by the graph.
segment.target: Audio output nodes are the destination for audio processed by the graph.

segment.source: Audio can be routed out of the graph to audio output devices, audio files, or custom code.
segment.target: Audio can be routed out of the graph to audio output devices, audio files, or custom code.

segment.source: The last type of node is a submix node which takes audio from one or more nodes and combines them into a single output that can be routed to other nodes in the graph.
segment.target: The last type of node is a submix node which takes audio from one or more nodes and combines them into a single output that can be routed to other nodes in the graph.

segment.source: After all of the nodes have been created and the connections between them set up, you simply start the audio graph and the audio data flows from the input nodes, through any submix nodes, to the output nodes.
segment.target: After all of the nodes have been created and the connections between them set up, you simply start the audio graph and the audio data flows from the input nodes, through any submix nodes, to the output nodes.

segment.source: This model makes scenarios like recording from a device's microphone to an audio file, playing audio from a file to a device's speaker, or mixing audio from multiple sources quick and easy to implement.
segment.target: This model makes scenarios like recording from a device's microphone to an audio file, playing audio from a file to a device's speaker, or mixing audio from multiple sources quick and easy to implement.

segment.source: Additional scenarios are enabled with the addition of audio effects to the audio graph.
segment.target: Additional scenarios are enabled with the addition of audio effects to the audio graph.

segment.source: Every node in an audio graph can be populated with zero or more audio effects that perform audio processing on the audio passing through the node.
segment.target: Every node in an audio graph can be populated with zero or more audio effects that perform audio processing on the audio passing through the node.

segment.source: There are several built-in effects such as echo, equalizer, limiting, and reverb that can be attached to an audio node with just a few lines of code.
segment.target: There are several built-in effects such as echo, equalizer, limiting, and reverb that can be attached to an audio node with just a few lines of code.

segment.source: You can also create your own custom audio effects that work exactly the same as the built-in effects.
segment.target: You can also create your own custom audio effects that work exactly the same as the built-in effects.

segment.source: Note
segment.target: Note

segment.source: The AudioGraph UWP sample implements the code discussed in this overview.
segment.target: The AudioGraph UWP sample implements the code discussed in this overview.

segment.source: You can download the sample to see the code in context or to use as a starting point for your own app.
segment.target: You can download the sample to see the code in context or to use as a starting point for your own app.

segment.source: Choosing Windows Runtime AudioGraph or XAudio2
segment.target: Choosing Windows Runtime AudioGraph or XAudio2

segment.source: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs offer functionality that can also be implemented using the COM-based XAudio2 APIs.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs offer functionality that can also be implemented using the COM-based XAudio2 APIs.

segment.source: The following are features of the Windows Runtime audio graph framework that differ from XAudio2.
segment.target: The following are features of the Windows Runtime audio graph framework that differ from XAudio2.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs are significantly easier to use than XAudio2.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs are significantly easier to use than XAudio2.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs can be used from C# - in addition to being supported for C++.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs can be used from C# - in addition to being supported for C++.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs can use audio files, including compressed file formats, directly.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs can use audio files, including compressed file formats, directly.

segment.source: XAudio2 only operates on audio buffers and does not provide any file I/O capabilities.
segment.target: XAudio2 only operates on audio buffers and does not provide any file I/O capabilities.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs can use the low-latency audio pipeline in Windows 10.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs can use the low-latency audio pipeline in Windows 10.

segment.source: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs supports automatic endpoint switching when default endpoint parameters are used.
segment.target: The Windows Runtime audio graph APIs supports automatic endpoint switching when default endpoint parameters are used.

segment.source: For example, if the user switches from a device's speaker to a headset, the audio is automatically redirected to the new input.
segment.target: For example, if the user switches from a device's speaker to a headset, the audio is automatically redirected to the new input.

segment.source: AudioGraph class
segment.target: AudioGraph class

segment.source: The AudioGraph class is the parent of all nodes that make up the graph.
segment.target: The AudioGraph class is the parent of all nodes that make up the graph.

segment.source: Use this object to create instances of all of the audio node types.
segment.target: Use this object to create instances of all of the audio node types.

segment.source: Create an instance of the AudioGraph class by initializing an AudioGraphSettings object, containing configuration settings for the graph, and then calling AudioGraph.CreateAsync.
segment.target: Create an instance of the AudioGraph class by initializing an AudioGraphSettings object, containing configuration settings for the graph, and then calling AudioGraph.CreateAsync.

segment.source: The returned CreateAudioGraphResult gives access to the created audio graph or provides an error value if audio graph creation fails.
segment.target: The returned CreateAudioGraphResult gives access to the created audio graph or provides an error value if audio graph creation fails.

segment.source: DeclareAudioGraph
segment.target: DeclareAudioGraph

segment.source: InitAudioGraph
segment.target: InitAudioGraph

segment.source: All audio node types are created by using the Create\* methods of the AudioGraph class.
segment.target: All audio node types are created by using the Create\* methods of the AudioGraph class.

segment.source: The AudioGraph.Start method causes the audio graph to start processing audio data.
segment.target: The AudioGraph.Start method causes the audio graph to start processing audio data.

segment.source: The AudioGraph.Stop method stops audio processing.
segment.target: The AudioGraph.Stop method stops audio processing.

segment.source: Each node in the graph can be started and stopped independently while the graph is running, but no nodes are active when the graph is stopped.
segment.target: Each node in the graph can be started and stopped independently while the graph is running, but no nodes are active when the graph is stopped.

segment.source: ResetAllNodes causes all nodes in the graph to discard any data currently in their audio buffers.
segment.target: ResetAllNodes causes all nodes in the graph to discard any data currently in their audio buffers.

segment.source: The QuantumStarted event occurs when the graph is starting the processing of a new quantum of audio data.
segment.target: The QuantumStarted event occurs when the graph is starting the processing of a new quantum of audio data.

segment.source: The QuantumProcessed event occurs when the processing of a quantum is completed.
segment.target: The QuantumProcessed event occurs when the processing of a quantum is completed.

segment.source: The only AudioGraphSettings property that is required is AudioRenderCategory.
segment.target: The only AudioGraphSettings property that is required is AudioRenderCategory.

segment.source: Specifying this value allows the system to optimize the audio pipeline for the specified category.
segment.target: Specifying this value allows the system to optimize the audio pipeline for the specified category.

segment.source: The quantum size of the audio graph determines the number of samples that are processed at one time.
segment.target: The quantum size of the audio graph determines the number of samples that are processed at one time.

segment.source: By default, the quantum size is 10 ms based at the default sample rate.
segment.target: By default, the quantum size is 10 ms based at the default sample rate.

segment.source: If you specify a custom quantum size by setting the DesiredSamplesPerQuantum property, you must also set the QuantumSizeSelectionMode property to ClosestToDesired or the supplied value is ignored.
segment.target: If you specify a custom quantum size by setting the DesiredSamplesPerQuantum property, you must also set the QuantumSizeSelectionMode property to ClosestToDesired or the supplied value is ignored.

segment.source: If this value is used, the system will choose a quantum size as close as possible to the one you specify.
segment.target: If this value is used, the system will choose a quantum size as close as possible to the one you specify.

segment.source: To determine the actual quantum size, check the SamplesPerQuantum of the AudioGraph after it has been created.
segment.target: To determine the actual quantum size, check the SamplesPerQuantum of the AudioGraph after it has been created.

segment.source: If you only plan to use the audio graph with files and don't plan to output to an audio device, it is recommended that you use the default quantum size by not setting the DesiredSamplesPerQuantum property.
segment.target: If you only plan to use the audio graph with files and don't plan to output to an audio device, it is recommended that you use the default quantum size by not setting the DesiredSamplesPerQuantum property.

segment.source: The DesiredRenderDeviceAudioProcessing property determines the amount of processing the primary render device performs on the output of the audio graph.
segment.target: The DesiredRenderDeviceAudioProcessing property determines the amount of processing the primary render device performs on the output of the audio graph.

segment.source: The Default setting allows the system to use the default audio processing for the specified audio render category.
segment.target: The Default setting allows the system to use the default audio processing for the specified audio render category.

segment.source: This processing can significantly improve the sound of audio on some devices, particularly mobile devices with small speakers.
segment.target: This processing can significantly improve the sound of audio on some devices, particularly mobile devices with small speakers.

segment.source: The Raw setting can improve performance by minimizing the amount of signal processing performed, but can result in inferior sound quality on some devices.
segment.target: The Raw setting can improve performance by minimizing the amount of signal processing performed, but can result in inferior sound quality on some devices.

segment.source: If the QuantumSizeSelectionMode is set to LowestLatency, the audio graph will automatically use Raw for DesiredRenderDeviceAudioProcessing.
segment.target: If the QuantumSizeSelectionMode is set to LowestLatency, the audio graph will automatically use Raw for DesiredRenderDeviceAudioProcessing.

segment.source: The EncodingProperties determines the audio format used by the graph.
segment.target: The EncodingProperties determines the audio format used by the graph.

segment.source: Only 32-bit float formats are supported.
segment.target: Only 32-bit float formats are supported.

segment.source: The PrimaryRenderDevice sets the primary render device for the audio graph.
segment.target: The PrimaryRenderDevice sets the primary render device for the audio graph.

segment.source: If you don't set this, the default system device is used.
segment.target: If you don't set this, the default system device is used.

segment.source: The primary render device is used to calculate the quantum sizes for other nodes in the graph.
segment.target: The primary render device is used to calculate the quantum sizes for other nodes in the graph.

segment.source: If there are no audio render devices present on the system, audio graph creation will fail.
segment.target: If there are no audio render devices present on the system, audio graph creation will fail.

segment.source: You can let the audio graph use the default audio render device or use the Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceInformation class to get a list of the system's available audio render devices by calling FindAllAsync and passing in the audio render device selector returned by Windows.Media.Devices.MediaDevice.GetAudioRenderSelector.
segment.target: You can let the audio graph use the default audio render device or use the Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceInformation class to get a list of the system's available audio render devices by calling FindAllAsync and passing in the audio render device selector returned by Windows.Media.Devices.MediaDevice.GetAudioRenderSelector.

segment.source: You can choose one of the returned DeviceInformation objects programatically or show UI to allow the user to select a device and then use it to set the PrimaryRenderDevice property.
segment.target: You can choose one of the returned DeviceInformation objects programatically or show UI to allow the user to select a device and then use it to set the PrimaryRenderDevice property.

segment.source: EnumerateAudioRenderDevices
segment.target: EnumerateAudioRenderDevices

segment.source: Device input node
segment.target: Device input node

segment.source: A device input node feeds audio into the graph from an audio capture device connected to the system, such as a microphone.
segment.target: A device input node feeds audio into the graph from an audio capture device connected to the system, such as a microphone.

segment.source: Create a DeviceInputNode object that uses the system's default audio capture device by calling CreateDeviceInputNodeAsync.
segment.target: Create a DeviceInputNode object that uses the system's default audio capture device by calling CreateDeviceInputNodeAsync.

segment.source: Provide an AudioRenderCategory to allow the system to optimize the audio pipeline for the specified category.
segment.target: Provide an AudioRenderCategory to allow the system to optimize the audio pipeline for the specified category.

segment.source: DeclareDeviceInputNode
segment.target: DeclareDeviceInputNode

segment.source: CreateDeviceInputNode
segment.target: CreateDeviceInputNode

segment.source: If you want to specify a specific audio capture device for the device input node, you can use the Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceInformation class to get a list of the system's available audio capture devices by calling FindAllAsync and passing in the audio render device selector returned by Windows.Media.Devices.MediaDevice.GetAudioRenderSelector.
segment.target: If you want to specify a specific audio capture device for the device input node, you can use the Windows.Devices.Enumeration.DeviceInformation class to get a list of the system's available audio capture devices by calling FindAllAsync and passing in the audio render device selector returned by Windows.Media.Devices.MediaDevice.GetAudioRenderSelector.

segment.source: You can choose one of the returned DeviceInformation objects programmatically or show UI to allow the user to select a device and then pass it into CreateDeviceInputNodeAsync.
segment.target: You can choose one of the returned DeviceInformation objects programmatically or show UI to allow the user to select a device and then pass it into CreateDeviceInputNodeAsync.

segment.source: EnumerateAudioCaptureDevices
segment.target: EnumerateAudioCaptureDevices

segment.source: Device output node
segment.target: Device output node

segment.source: A device output node pushes audio from the graph to an audio render device, such as speakers or a headset.
segment.target: A device output node pushes audio from the graph to an audio render device, such as speakers or a headset.

segment.source: Create a DeviceOutputNode by calling CreateDeviceOutputNodeAsync.
segment.target: Create a DeviceOutputNode by calling CreateDeviceOutputNodeAsync.

segment.source: The output node uses the PrimaryRenderDevice of the audio graph.
segment.target: The output node uses the PrimaryRenderDevice of the audio graph.

segment.source: DeclareDeviceOutputNode
segment.target: DeclareDeviceOutputNode

segment.source: CreateDeviceOutputNode
segment.target: CreateDeviceOutputNode

segment.source: File input node
segment.target: File input node

segment.source: A file input node allows you to feed data from an audio file into the graph.
segment.target: A file input node allows you to feed data from an audio file into the graph.

segment.source: Create an AudioFileInputNode by calling CreateFileInputNodeAsync.
segment.target: Create an AudioFileInputNode by calling CreateFileInputNodeAsync.

segment.source: DeclareFileInputNode
segment.target: DeclareFileInputNode

segment.source: CreateFileInputNode
segment.target: CreateFileInputNode

segment.source: File input nodes support the following file formats: mp3, wav, wma, m4a
segment.target: File input nodes support the following file formats: mp3, wav, wma, m4a

segment.source: Set the StartTime property to specify the time offset into the file where playback should begin.
segment.target: Set the StartTime property to specify the time offset into the file where playback should begin.

segment.source: If this property is null, the beginning of the file is used.
segment.target: If this property is null, the beginning of the file is used.

segment.source: Set the EndTime property to specify the time offset into the file where playback should end.
segment.target: Set the EndTime property to specify the time offset into the file where playback should end.

segment.source: If this property is null, the end of the file is used.
segment.target: If this property is null, the end of the file is used.

segment.source: The start time value must be lower than the end time value, and the end time value must be less than or equal to the duration of the audio file, which can be determined by checking the Duration property value.
segment.target: The start time value must be lower than the end time value, and the end time value must be less than or equal to the duration of the audio file, which can be determined by checking the Duration property value.

segment.source: Seek to a position in the audio file by calling Seek and specifying the time offset into the file to which the playback position should be moved.
segment.target: Seek to a position in the audio file by calling Seek and specifying the time offset into the file to which the playback position should be moved.

segment.source: The specified value must be within the StartTime and EndTime range.
segment.target: The specified value must be within the StartTime and EndTime range.

segment.source: Get the current playback position of the node with the read-only Position property.
segment.target: Get the current playback position of the node with the read-only Position property.

segment.source: Enable looping of the audio file by setting the LoopCount property.
segment.target: Enable looping of the audio file by setting the LoopCount property.

segment.source: When non-null, this value indicates the number of times the file will be played in after the initial playback.
segment.target: When non-null, this value indicates the number of times the file will be played in after the initial playback.

segment.source: So, for example, setting LoopCount to 1 will cause the file to be played 2 times in total, and setting it to 5 will cause the file to be played 6 times in total.
segment.target: So, for example, setting LoopCount to 1 will cause the file to be played 2 times in total, and setting it to 5 will cause the file to be played 6 times in total.

segment.source: Setting LoopCount to null causes the file to be looped indefinitely.
segment.target: Setting LoopCount to null causes the file to be looped indefinitely.

segment.source: To stop looping, set the value to 0.
segment.target: To stop looping, set the value to 0.

segment.source: Adjust the speed at which the audio file is played back by setting the PlaybackSpeedFactor.
segment.target: Adjust the speed at which the audio file is played back by setting the PlaybackSpeedFactor.

segment.source: A value of 1 indicates the original speed of the file, .5 is half-speed, and 2 is double speed.
segment.target: A value of 1 indicates the original speed of the file, .5 is half-speed, and 2 is double speed.

segment.source: File output node
segment.target: File output node

segment.source: A file output node lets you direct audio data from the graph into an audio file.
segment.target: A file output node lets you direct audio data from the graph into an audio file.

segment.source: Create an AudioFileOutputNode by calling CreateFileOutputNodeAsync.
segment.target: Create an AudioFileOutputNode by calling CreateFileOutputNodeAsync.

segment.source: DeclareFileOutputNode
segment.target: DeclareFileOutputNode

segment.source: CreateFileOutputNode
segment.target: CreateFileOutputNode

segment.source: File output nodes support the following file formats: mp3, wav, wma, m4a
segment.target: File output nodes support the following file formats: mp3, wav, wma, m4a

segment.source: You must call AudioFileOutputNode.Stop to stop the node's processing before calling AudioFileOutputNode.FinalizeAsync or an exception will be thrown.
segment.target: You must call AudioFileOutputNode.Stop to stop the node's processing before calling AudioFileOutputNode.FinalizeAsync or an exception will be thrown.

segment.source: Audio frame input node
segment.target: Audio frame input node

segment.source: An audio frame input node allows you to push audio data that you generate in your own code into the audio graph.
segment.target: An audio frame input node allows you to push audio data that you generate in your own code into the audio graph.

segment.source: This enables scenarios like creating a custom software synthesizer.
segment.target: This enables scenarios like creating a custom software synthesizer.

segment.source: Create an AudioFrameInputNode by calling CreateFrameInputNode.
segment.target: Create an AudioFrameInputNode by calling CreateFrameInputNode.

segment.source: DeclareFrameInputNode
segment.target: DeclareFrameInputNode

segment.source: CreateFrameInputNode
segment.target: CreateFrameInputNode

segment.source: The FrameInputNode.QuantumStarted event is raised when the audio graph is ready to begin processing the next quantum of audio data.
segment.target: The FrameInputNode.QuantumStarted event is raised when the audio graph is ready to begin processing the next quantum of audio data.

segment.source: You supply your custom generated audio data from within the handler to this event.
segment.target: You supply your custom generated audio data from within the handler to this event.

segment.source: QuantumStarted
segment.target: QuantumStarted

segment.source: The FrameInputNodeQuantumStartedEventArgs object passed into the QuantumStarted event handler exposes the RequiredSamples property that indicates how many samples the audio graph needs to fill up the quantum to be processed.
segment.target: The FrameInputNodeQuantumStartedEventArgs object passed into the QuantumStarted event handler exposes the RequiredSamples property that indicates how many samples the audio graph needs to fill up the quantum to be processed.

segment.source: Call AudioFrameInputNode.AddFrame to pass an AudioFrame object filled with audio data into the graph.
segment.target: Call AudioFrameInputNode.AddFrame to pass an AudioFrame object filled with audio data into the graph.

segment.source: An example implementation of the GenerateAudioData helper method is shown below.
segment.target: An example implementation of the GenerateAudioData helper method is shown below.

segment.source: To populate an AudioFrame with audio data, you must get access to the underlying memory buffer of the audio frame.
segment.target: To populate an AudioFrame with audio data, you must get access to the underlying memory buffer of the audio frame.

segment.source: To do this you must initialize the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface by adding the following code within your namespace.
segment.target: To do this you must initialize the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface by adding the following code within your namespace.

segment.source: ComImportIMemoryBufferByteAccess
segment.target: ComImportIMemoryBufferByteAccess

segment.source: The following code shows an example implementation of a GenerateAudioData helper method that creates an AudioFrame and populates it with audio data.
segment.target: The following code shows an example implementation of a GenerateAudioData helper method that creates an AudioFrame and populates it with audio data.

segment.source: GenerateAudioData
segment.target: GenerateAudioData

segment.source: Because this method accesses the raw buffer underlying the Windows Runtime types, it must be declared using the unsafe keyword.
segment.target: Because this method accesses the raw buffer underlying the Windows Runtime types, it must be declared using the unsafe keyword.

segment.source: You must also configure your project in Microsoft Visual Studio to allow the compilation of unsafe code by opening the project's Properties page, clicking the Build property page, and selecting the Allow Unsafe Code checkbox.
segment.target: You must also configure your project in Microsoft Visual Studio to allow the compilation of unsafe code by opening the project's Properties page, clicking the Build property page, and selecting the Allow Unsafe Code checkbox.

segment.source: Initialize a new instance of AudioFrame, in the Windows.Media namespace, by passing in the desired buffer size to the constructor.
segment.target: Initialize a new instance of AudioFrame, in the Windows.Media namespace, by passing in the desired buffer size to the constructor.

segment.source: The buffer size is the number of samples multiplied by the size of each sample.
segment.target: The buffer size is the number of samples multiplied by the size of each sample.

segment.source: Get the AudioBuffer of the audio frame by calling LockBuffer.
segment.target: Get the AudioBuffer of the audio frame by calling LockBuffer.

segment.source: Get an instance of the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface from the audio buffer by calling CreateReference.
segment.target: Get an instance of the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface from the audio buffer by calling CreateReference.

segment.source: Get a pointer to raw audio buffer data by calling IMemoryBufferByteAccess.GetBuffer and cast it to the sample data type of the audio data.
segment.target: Get a pointer to raw audio buffer data by calling IMemoryBufferByteAccess.GetBuffer and cast it to the sample data type of the audio data.

segment.source: Fill the buffer with data and return the AudioFrame for submission into the audio graph.
segment.target: Fill the buffer with data and return the AudioFrame for submission into the audio graph.

segment.source: Audio frame output node
segment.target: Audio frame output node

segment.source: An audio frame output node allows you to receive and process audio data output from the audio graph with custom code that you create.
segment.target: An audio frame output node allows you to receive and process audio data output from the audio graph with custom code that you create.

segment.source: An example scenario for this is performing signal analysis on the audio output.
segment.target: An example scenario for this is performing signal analysis on the audio output.

segment.source: Create an AudioFrameOutputNode by calling CreateFrameOutputNode.
segment.target: Create an AudioFrameOutputNode by calling CreateFrameOutputNode.

segment.source: DeclareFrameOutputNode
segment.target: DeclareFrameOutputNode

segment.source: CreateFrameOutputNode
segment.target: CreateFrameOutputNode

segment.source: The AudioGraph.QuantumProcessed event is raised when the audio graph has completed processing a quantum of audio data.
segment.target: The AudioGraph.QuantumProcessed event is raised when the audio graph has completed processing a quantum of audio data.

segment.source: You can access the audio data from within the handler for this event.
segment.target: You can access the audio data from within the handler for this event.

segment.source: QuantumProcessed
segment.target: QuantumProcessed

segment.source: Call GetFrame to get an AudioFrame object filled with audio data from the graph.
segment.target: Call GetFrame to get an AudioFrame object filled with audio data from the graph.

segment.source: An example implementation of the ProcessFrameOutput helper method is shown below.
segment.target: An example implementation of the ProcessFrameOutput helper method is shown below.

segment.source: ProcessFrameOutput
segment.target: ProcessFrameOutput

segment.source: Like the audio frame input node example above, you will need to declare the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface and configure your project to allow unsafe code in order to access the underlying audio buffer.
segment.target: Like the audio frame input node example above, you will need to declare the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface and configure your project to allow unsafe code in order to access the underlying audio buffer.

segment.source: Get the AudioBuffer of the audio frame by calling LockBuffer.
segment.target: Get the AudioBuffer of the audio frame by calling LockBuffer.

segment.source: Get an instance of the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface from the audio buffer by calling CreateReference.
segment.target: Get an instance of the IMemoryBufferByteAccess COM interface from the audio buffer by calling CreateReference.

segment.source: Get a pointer to raw audio buffer data by calling IMemoryBufferByteAccess.GetBuffer and cast it to the sample data type of the audio data.
segment.target: Get a pointer to raw audio buffer data by calling IMemoryBufferByteAccess.GetBuffer and cast it to the sample data type of the audio data.

segment.source: Node connections and submix nodes
segment.target: Node connections and submix nodes

segment.source: All input nodes types expose the AddOutgoingConnection method that routes the audio produced by the node to the node that is passed into the method.
segment.target: All input nodes types expose the AddOutgoingConnection method that routes the audio produced by the node to the node that is passed into the method.

segment.source: The following example connects an AudioFileInputNode to an AudioDeviceOutputNode, which is a simple setup for playing an audio file on the device's speaker.
segment.target: The following example connects an AudioFileInputNode to an AudioDeviceOutputNode, which is a simple setup for playing an audio file on the device's speaker.

segment.source: AddOutgoingConnection1
segment.target: AddOutgoingConnection1

segment.source: You can create more than one connection from an input node to other nodes.
segment.target: You can create more than one connection from an input node to other nodes.

segment.source: The following example adds another connection from the AudioFileInputNode to an AudioFileOutputNode.
segment.target: The following example adds another connection from the AudioFileInputNode to an AudioFileOutputNode.

segment.source: Now, the audio from the audio file is played to the device's speaker and is also written out to an audio file.
segment.target: Now, the audio from the audio file is played to the device's speaker and is also written out to an audio file.

segment.source: AddOutgoingConnection2
segment.target: AddOutgoingConnection2

segment.source: Output nodes can also receive more than one connection from other nodes.
segment.target: Output nodes can also receive more than one connection from other nodes.

segment.source: In the following example a connection is made from a AudioDeviceInputNode to the AudioDeviceOutput node.
segment.target: In the following example a connection is made from a AudioDeviceInputNode to the AudioDeviceOutput node.

segment.source: Because the output node has connections from the file input node and the device input node, the output will contain a mix of audio from both sources.
segment.target: Because the output node has connections from the file input node and the device input node, the output will contain a mix of audio from both sources.

segment.source: AddOutgoingConnection provides an overload that lets you specify a gain value for the signal passing through the connection.
segment.target: AddOutgoingConnection provides an overload that lets you specify a gain value for the signal passing through the connection.

segment.source: AddOutgoingConnection3
segment.target: AddOutgoingConnection3

segment.source: Although output nodes can accept connections from multiple nodes, you may want to create an intermediate mix of signals from one or more nodes before passing the mix to an output.
segment.target: Although output nodes can accept connections from multiple nodes, you may want to create an intermediate mix of signals from one or more nodes before passing the mix to an output.

segment.source: For example, you may want to set the level or apply effects to a subset of the audio signals in a graph.
segment.target: For example, you may want to set the level or apply effects to a subset of the audio signals in a graph.

segment.source: To do this, use the AudioSubmixNode.
segment.target: To do this, use the AudioSubmixNode.

segment.source: You can connect to a submix node from one or more input nodes or other submix nodes.
segment.target: You can connect to a submix node from one or more input nodes or other submix nodes.

segment.source: In the following example, a new submix node is created with AudioGraph.CreateSubmixNode.
segment.target: In the following example, a new submix node is created with AudioGraph.CreateSubmixNode.

segment.source: Then, connections are added from a file input node and a frame output node to the submix node.
segment.target: Then, connections are added from a file input node and a frame output node to the submix node.

segment.source: Finally, the submix node is connected to a file output node.
segment.target: Finally, the submix node is connected to a file output node.

segment.source: CreateSubmixNode
segment.target: CreateSubmixNode

segment.source: Starting and stopping audio graph nodes
segment.target: Starting and stopping audio graph nodes

segment.source: When AudioGraph.Start is called, the audio graph begins processing audio data.
segment.target: When AudioGraph.Start is called, the audio graph begins processing audio data.

segment.source: Every node type provides Start and Stop methods that cause the individual node to start or stop processing data.
segment.target: Every node type provides Start and Stop methods that cause the individual node to start or stop processing data.

segment.source: When AudioGraph.Stop is called, all audio processing in the all nodes is stopped regardless of the state of individual nodes, but the state of each node can be set while the audio graph is stopped.
segment.target: When AudioGraph.Stop is called, all audio processing in the all nodes is stopped regardless of the state of individual nodes, but the state of each node can be set while the audio graph is stopped.

segment.source: For example, you could call Stop on an individual node while the graph is stopped and then call AudioGraph.Start, and the individual node will remain in the stopped state.
segment.target: For example, you could call Stop on an individual node while the graph is stopped and then call AudioGraph.Start, and the individual node will remain in the stopped state.

segment.source: All node types expose the ConsumeInput property that, when set to false, allows the node to continue audio processing but stops it from consuming any audio data being input from other nodes.
segment.target: All node types expose the ConsumeInput property that, when set to false, allows the node to continue audio processing but stops it from consuming any audio data being input from other nodes.

segment.source: All node types expose the Reset method that causes the node to discard any audio data currently in its buffer.
segment.target: All node types expose the Reset method that causes the node to discard any audio data currently in its buffer.

segment.source: Adding audio effects
segment.target: Adding audio effects

segment.source: The audio graph API allows you to add audio effects to every type of node in a graph.
segment.target: The audio graph API allows you to add audio effects to every type of node in a graph.

segment.source: Output nodes, input nodes, and submix nodes can each have an unlimited number of audio effects, limited only by the capabilities of the hardware.The following example demonstrates adding the built-in echo effect to a submix node.
segment.target: Output nodes, input nodes, and submix nodes can each have an unlimited number of audio effects, limited only by the capabilities of the hardware.The following example demonstrates adding the built-in echo effect to a submix node.

segment.source: AddEffect
segment.target: AddEffect

segment.source: All audio effects implement IAudioEffectDefinition.
segment.target: All audio effects implement IAudioEffectDefinition.

segment.source: Every node exposes an EffectDefinitions property representing the list of effects applied to that node.
segment.target: Every node exposes an EffectDefinitions property representing the list of effects applied to that node.

segment.source: Add an effect by adding it's definition object to the list.
segment.target: Add an effect by adding it's definition object to the list.

segment.source: There are several effect definition classes that are provided in the Windows.Media.Audio namespace.
segment.target: There are several effect definition classes that are provided in the Windows.Media.Audio namespace.

segment.source: These include:
segment.target: These include:

segment.source: EchoEffectDefinition
segment.target: EchoEffectDefinition

segment.source: EqualizerEffectDefinition
segment.target: EqualizerEffectDefinition

segment.source: LimiterEffectDefinition
segment.target: LimiterEffectDefinition

segment.source: ReverbEffectDefinition
segment.target: ReverbEffectDefinition

segment.source: You can create your own audio effects that implement IAudioEffectDefinition and apply them to any node in an audio graph.
segment.target: You can create your own audio effects that implement IAudioEffectDefinition and apply them to any node in an audio graph.

segment.source: Every node type exposes a DisableEffectsByDefinition method that disables all effects in the node's EffectDefinitions list that were added using the specified definition.
segment.target: Every node type exposes a DisableEffectsByDefinition method that disables all effects in the node's EffectDefinitions list that were added using the specified definition.

segment.source: EnableEffectsByDefinition enables the effects with the specified definition.
segment.target: EnableEffectsByDefinition enables the effects with the specified definition.
